Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of a Question Prompt List Intervention for Older Patients Considering Major Surgery

Background: Poor preoperative communication can result in unwanted treatment and postoperative conflict. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a question prompt list (QPL) intervention compared to usual care on patient engagement and well-being among older patients considering major surgery.

Methods: This randomised clinical trial employed a stepped-wedge design, with patients randomly assigned to a QPL intervention (n=223) or usual care (n=223) based on the timing of their visit with one of 40 surgeons at five US study sites. Participants were 60 years or older with at least one comorbidity and an oncologic or vascular problem treatable with major surgery. The intervention consisted of a brochure of 11 questions and an endorsement letter from the surgeon. Primary outcomes included the number and type of questions asked during the surgical visit and patient-reported Perceived Efficacy in Patient-Physician Interactions scale. Randomisation was by intent-to-treat, and outcome assessors were blinded.

Results: Of 1319 eligible patients, 446 were randomised. The mean age was 71.8 years, and 55.8% were male. No significant differences were observed between groups for primary outcomes. The difference in MYCaW scores for family members was greater in usual care (effect estimate, 1.51; 95% CI, 0.28-2.74; P=.008). When the QPL intervention group was restricted to patients with clear evidence they reviewed the QPL, a nonsignificant increase in effect size was noted for questions about options, expectations, and risks. No adverse events were reported.

Interpretation: The QPL intervention did not significantly enhance patient engagement or well-being. Effective change may require addressing clinician communication directly.

Trial Registration: ClinicalTrials.gov NCT02623335

Funding: Not specified.
